an4.137:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four individuals are found in the world.

an4.137:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo na sīlagaru hoti na sīlādhipateyyo, na samādhigaru hoti na samādhādhipateyyo, na paññāgaru hoti na paññādhipateyyo.
an4.137:1.3.eng: One individual doesn’t value or submit to ethics, immersion, or wisdom.

an4.137:2.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo sīlagaru hoti sīlādhipateyyo, na samādhigaru hoti na samādhādhipateyyo, na paññāgaru hoti na paññādhipateyyo.
an4.137:2.1.eng: One individual values and submits to ethics, but not to immersion or wisdom.

an4.137:3.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo sīlagaru hoti sīlādhipateyyo, samādhigaru hoti samādhādhipateyyo, na paññāgaru hoti na paññādhipateyyo.
an4.137:3.1.eng: One individual values and submits to ethics and immersion, but not wisdom.

an4.137:4.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo sīlagaru hoti sīlādhipateyyo, samādhigaru hoti samādhādhipateyyo, paññāgaru hoti paññādhipateyyo.
an4.137:4.1.eng: One individual values and submits to ethics, immersion, and wisdom.

an4.137:4.2.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an4.137:4.2.eng: These are the four individuals found in the world.”

an4.138:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four individuals are found in the world.

an4.138:1.3.eng: One is on retreat in body, but not mind;

an4.138:1.4.eng: one is on retreat in mind, but not body;

an4.138:1.5.eng: one is on retreat in neither body nor mind; and

an4.138:1.6.eng: one is on retreat in both body and mind.

an4.138:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo nikaṭṭhakāyo hoti anikaṭṭhacitto?
an4.138:2.1.eng: And how is an individual on retreat in body, but not mind?

an4.138:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevati.
an4.138:2.2.eng: It’s when an individual frequents remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.

an4.138:2.3.pli: So tattha kāmavitakkampi vitakketi byāpādavitakkampi vitakketi vihiṃsāvitakkampi vitakketi.
an4.138:2.3.eng: But they think sensual, malicious, and cruel thoughts.

an4.138:2.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo nikaṭṭhakāyo hoti anikaṭṭhacitto.
an4.138:2.4.eng: That’s how an individual is on retreat in body, but not mind.

an4.138:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo anikaṭṭhakāyo hoti nikaṭṭhacitto?
an4.138:3.1.eng: And how is an individual on retreat in mind, but not body?

an4.138:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo naheva kho araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevati.
an4.138:3.2.eng: It’s when an individual doesn’t frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.

an4.138:3.3.pli: So tattha nekkhammavitakkampi vitakketi abyāpādavitakkampi vitakketi avihiṃsāvitakkampi vitakketi.
an4.138:3.3.eng: But they think thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.

an4.138:3.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo anikaṭṭhakāyo hoti nikaṭṭhacitto.
an4.138:3.4.eng: That’s how an individual is on retreat in mind, but not body.

an4.138:4.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo anikaṭṭhakāyo ca hoti anikaṭṭhacitto ca?
an4.138:4.1.eng: And how is an individual on retreat in neither body nor mind?

an4.138:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo naheva kho araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevati.
an4.138:4.2.eng: It’s when an individual doesn’t frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.

an4.138:4.3.pli: So tattha kāmavitakkampi vitakketi byāpādavitakkampi vitakketi vihiṃsāvitakkampi vitakketi.
an4.138:4.3.eng: And they think sensual, malicious, and cruel thoughts.

an4.138:4.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo anikaṭṭhakāyo ca hoti anikaṭṭhacitto ca.
an4.138:4.4.eng: That’s how an individual is on retreat in neither body nor mind.

an4.138:5.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo nikaṭṭhakāyo ca hoti nikaṭṭhacitto ca?
an4.138:5.1.eng: And how is an individual on retreat in both body and mind?

an4.138:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevati.
an4.138:5.2.eng: It’s when an individual frequents remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.

an4.138:5.3.pli: So tattha nekkhammavitakkampi vitakketi abyāpādavitakkampi vitakketi avihiṃsāvitakkampi vitakketi.
an4.138:5.3.eng: And they think thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.

an4.138:5.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo nikaṭṭhakāyo ca hoti nikaṭṭhacitto ca.
an4.138:5.4.eng: That’s how an individual is on retreat in both body and mind.

an4.138:5.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an4.138:5.5.eng: These are the four individuals found in the world.”

an4.139:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four Dhamma speakers.

an4.139:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco dhammakathiko appañca bhāsati asahitañca;
an4.139:1.3.eng: One Dhamma speaker speaks little and off topic.

an4.139:1.4.pli: parisā cassa na kusalā hoti sahitāsahitassa.
an4.139:1.4.eng: And their assembly can’t tell what’s on topic and what’s off topic.

an4.139:1.5.pli: Evarūpo, bhikkhave, dhammakathiko evarūpāya parisāya dhammakathikotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.139:1.5.eng: Such an assembly regards such a Dhamma speaker simply as a Dhamma speaker.

an4.139:2.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco dhammakathiko appañca bhāsati sahitañca;
an4.139:2.1.eng: One Dhamma speaker speaks little but stays on topic.

an4.139:2.2.eng: And their assembly can tell what’s on topic and what’s off topic.

an4.139:2.3.pli: Evarūpo, bhikkhave, dhammakathiko evarūpāya parisāya dhammakathikotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.139:2.3.eng: Such an assembly regards such a Dhamma speaker simply as a Dhamma speaker.

an4.139:3.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco dhammakathiko bahuñca bhāsati asahitañca;
an4.139:3.1.eng: One Dhamma speaker speaks much but off topic.

an4.139:3.2.pli: parisā cassa na kusalā hoti sahitāsahitassa.
an4.139:3.2.eng: And their assembly can’t tell what’s on topic and what’s off topic.

an4.139:3.3.pli: Evarūpo, bhikkhave, dhammakathiko evarūpāya parisāya dhammakathikotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.139:3.3.eng: Such an assembly regards such a Dhamma speaker simply as a Dhamma speaker.

an4.139:4.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco dhammakathiko bahuñca bhāsati sahitañca;
an4.139:4.1.eng: One Dhamma speaker speaks much and stays on topic.

an4.139:4.2.eng: And their assembly can tell what’s on topic and what’s off topic.

an4.139:4.3.pli: Evarūpo, bhikkhave, dhammakathiko evarūpāya parisāya dhammakathikotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.139:4.3.eng: Such an assembly regards such a Dhamma speaker simply as a Dhamma speaker.

an4.139:4.4.eng: These are the four Dhamma speakers.”

an4.14:1.3.eng: The efforts to restrain, to give up, to develop, and to preserve.

an4.14:1.4.eng: And what, mendicants, is the effort to restrain?

an4.14:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
an4.14:1.5.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

an4.14:1.6.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ, cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
an4.14:1.6.eng: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.

an4.14:1.7.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

an4.14:1.8.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

an4.14:1.9.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

an4.14:1.10.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

an4.14:1.11.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī,
an4.14:1.11.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

an4.14:1.12.pli: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṃ, manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
an4.14:1.12.eng: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.

an4.14:1.13.eng: This is called the effort to restrain.

an4.14:2.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is the effort to give up?

an4.14:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gameti;
an4.14:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual,

an4.14:2.4.eng: or cruel thought that’s arisen, but gives it up, gets rid of it, eliminates it, and obliterates it.

an4.14:2.5.pli: uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gameti.
an4.14:2.5.eng: They don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.

an4.14:2.6.eng: This is called the effort to give up.

an4.14:3.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is the effort to develop?

an4.14:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ,
an4.14:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness,

an4.14:3.8.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
an4.14:3.8.eng: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

an4.14:3.9.eng: This is called the effort to develop.

an4.14:4.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is the effort to preserve?

an4.14:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṃ bhaddakaṃ samādhinimittaṃ anurakkhati aṭṭhikasaññaṃ puḷavakasaññaṃ vinīlakasaññaṃ vicchiddakasaññaṃ uddhumātakasaññaṃ.
an4.14:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant preserves a meditation subject that’s a fine basis of immersion: the perception of a skeleton, a worm-infested corpse, a livid corpse, a split open corpse, or a bloated corpse.

an4.14:4.3.eng: This is called the effort to preserve.

an4.14:5.4.eng: taught by the Kinsman of the Sun.

an4.14:5.5.eng: Any mendicant who keenly applies these

an4.14:5.6.eng: may attain the ending of suffering.”

an4.140:1.3.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, vādī atthato pariyādānaṃ gacchati, no byañjanato;
an4.140:1.3.eng: There’s a speaker who runs out of meaningful things to say, but not of ways of phrasing things.

an4.140:1.4.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, vādī byañjanato pariyādānaṃ gacchati, no atthato;
an4.140:1.4.eng: There’s a speaker who runs out of ways of phrasing things, but not of meaningful things to say.

an4.140:1.5.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, vādī atthato ca byañjanato ca pariyādānaṃ gacchati;
an4.140:1.5.eng: There’s a speaker who runs out of both meaningful things to say, and ways of phrasing things.

an4.140:1.6.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, vādī nevatthato no byañjanato pariyādānaṃ gacchati.
an4.140:1.6.eng: There’s a speaker who never runs out of meaningful things to say, or ways of phrasing things.

an4.140:1.8.pli: Aṭṭhānametaṃ, bhikkhave, anavakāso yaṃ catūhi paṭisambhidāhi samannāgato atthato vā byañjanato vā pariyādānaṃ gaccheyyā”ti.
an4.140:1.8.eng: It is impossible, it cannot happen that someone accomplished in the four kinds of textual analysis will ever run out of meaningful things to say, or ways of phrasing things.”

an4.141:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of brightness.

an4.141:1.3.eng: The brightness of the moon, sun, fire, and wisdom.

an4.141:1.4.eng: These are the four kinds of brightness.

an4.141:1.5.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ catunnaṃ ābhānaṃ yadidaṃ paññābhā”ti.
an4.141:1.5.eng: The best of these four kinds of brightness is the brightness of wisdom.”

an4.142:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of radiance.

an4.142:1.3.eng: The radiance of the moon, sun, fire, and wisdom.

an4.142:1.4.eng: These are the four kinds of radiance.

an4.142:1.5.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ catunnaṃ pabhānaṃ yadidaṃ paññāpabhā”ti.
an4.142:1.5.eng: The best of these four kinds of radiance is the radiance of wisdom.”

an4.143:1.3.eng: The lights of the moon, sun, fire, and wisdom.

an4.143:1.5.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ catunnaṃ ālokānaṃ yadidaṃ paññāloko”ti.
an4.143:1.5.eng: The best of these four lights is the light of wisdom.”

an4.144:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are four kinds of shining.

an4.144:1.3.eng: The shining of the moon, sun, fire, and wisdom.

an4.144:1.4.eng: These are the four kinds of shining.

an4.144:1.5.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ catunnaṃ obhāsānaṃ yadidaṃ paññobhāso”ti.
an4.144:1.5.eng: The best of these four kinds of shining is the shining of wisdom.”

an4.145:1.3.eng: The lamps of the moon, sun, fire, and wisdom.

an4.145:1.5.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ catunnaṃ pajjotānaṃ yadidaṃ paññāpajjoto”ti.
an4.145:1.5.eng: The best of these four lamps is the lamp of wisdom.”

an4.146:1.3.pli: Kālena dhammassavanaṃ, kālena dhammasākacchā, kālena sammasanā, kālena vipassanā—
an4.146:1.3.eng: A time for listening to the teaching, a time for discussing the teaching, a time for serenity, and a time for discernment.

an4.147:1.1.pli: “Cattārome, bhikkhave, kālā sammā bhāviyamānā sammā anuparivattiyamānā anupubbena āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpenti.
an4.147:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when these four times are rightly developed and reiterated, they gradually lead to the ending of defilements.

an4.147:1.3.pli: Kālena dhammassavanaṃ, kālena dhammasākacchā, kālena sammasanā, kālena vipassanā—
an4.147:1.3.eng: A time for listening to the teaching, a time for discussing the teaching, a time for serenity, and a time for discernment.

an4.147:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro kālā sammā bhāviyamānā sammā anuparivattiyamānā anupubbena āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpenti.

an4.147:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uparipabbate thullaphusitake deve vassante taṃ udakaṃ yathāninnaṃ pavattamānaṃ pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūreti; pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūrā kusobbhe paripūrenti; kusobbhā paripūrā mahāsobbhe paripūrenti; mahāsobbhā paripūrā kunnadiyo paripūrenti; kunnadiyo paripūrā mahānadiyo paripūrenti; mahānadiyo paripūrā samuddaṃ paripūrenti.
an4.147:2.1.eng: It’s like when the heavens rain heavily on a mountain top, and the water flows downhill to fill the hollows, crevices, and creeks. As they become full, they fill up the pools. The pools fill up the lakes, the lakes fill up the streams, and the streams fill up the rivers. And as the rivers become full, they fill up the ocean.

an4.147:2.2.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, ime cattāro kālā sammā bhāviyamānā sammā anuparivattiyamānā anupubbena āsavānaṃ khayaṃ pāpentī”ti.
an4.147:2.2.eng: In the same way, when these four times are rightly developed and reiterated, they gradually lead to the ending of defilements.”

an4.148:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of bad conduct by way of speech.

an4.148:1.3.pli: Musāvādo, pisuṇā vācā, pharusā vācā, samphappalāpo—
an4.148:1.3.eng: Speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.

an4.148:1.4.eng: These are the four kinds of bad conduct by way of speech.”

an4.149:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of good conduct by way of speech.

an4.149:1.3.pli: Saccavācā, apisuṇā vācā, saṇhā vācā, mantabhāsā—
an4.149:1.3.eng: Speech that’s true, harmonious, gentle, and thoughtful.

an4.149:1.4.eng: These are the four kinds of good conduct by way of speech.”

an4.15:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four are regarded as foremost.

an4.15:1.3.eng: The foremost in size of incarnation is

an4.15:1.9.pli: Sadevake, bhikkhave, loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya tathāgato aggamakkhāyati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho.
an4.15:1.9.eng: In this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—a Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha is said to be the best.

an4.15:1.10.eng: These are the four regarded as foremost.

an4.15:2.1.eng: Rāhu is foremost in size of incarnation,

an4.15:3.2.eng: as far as the planet extends;

an4.15:3.3.eng: in all the world with its gods,

an4.150:1.3.eng: Ethics, immersion, wisdom, and freedom are essentials.

an4.151:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, and immersion.

an4.152:1.3.eng: The powers of faith, energy, mindfulness, and immersion.

an4.153:1.3.eng: The powers of wisdom, energy, blamelessness, and inclusiveness.

an4.154:1.3.eng: The powers of mindfulness, immersion, blamelessness, and inclusiveness.

an4.155:1.3.eng: The powers of reflection, development, blamelessness, and inclusiveness.

an4.156:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, an eon contains four uncountable periods.

an4.156:1.3.pli: Yadā, bhikkhave, kappo saṃvaṭṭati, taṃ na sukaraṃ saṅkhātuṃ—
an4.156:1.3.eng: When an eon contracts, it’s not easy to calculate

an4.156:1.4.pli: ettakāni vassānīti vā, ettakāni vassasatānīti vā, ettakāni vassasahassānīti vā, ettakāni vassasatasahassānīti vā.
an4.156:1.4.eng: how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it takes.

an4.156:2.1.pli: Yadā, bhikkhave, kappo saṃvaṭṭo tiṭṭhati, taṃ na sukaraṃ saṅkhātuṃ—
an4.156:2.1.eng: When an eon remains fully contracted, it’s not easy to calculate

an4.156:2.2.pli: ettakāni vassānīti vā, ettakāni vassasatānīti vā, ettakāni vassasahassānīti vā, ettakāni vassasatasahassānīti vā.
an4.156:2.2.eng: how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it takes.

an4.156:3.1.pli: Yadā, bhikkhave, kappo vivaṭṭati, taṃ na sukaraṃ saṅkhātuṃ—
an4.156:3.1.eng: When an eon expands, it’s not easy to calculate

an4.156:3.2.pli: ettakāni vassānīti vā, ettakāni vassasatānīti vā, ettakāni vassasahassānīti vā, ettakāni vassasatasahassānīti vā.
an4.156:3.2.eng: how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it takes.

an4.156:4.1.pli: Yadā, bhikkhave, kappo vivaṭṭo tiṭṭhati, taṃ na sukaraṃ saṅkhātuṃ—
an4.156:4.1.eng: When an eon remains fully expanded, it’s not easy to calculate

an4.156:4.2.pli: ettakāni vassānīti vā, ettakāni vassasatānīti vā, ettakāni vassasahassānīti vā, ettakāni vassasatasahassānīti vā.
an4.156:4.2.eng: how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it takes.

an4.156:4.3.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri kappassa asaṅkhyeyyānī”ti.
an4.156:4.3.eng: These are the four uncountable periods of an eon.”

an4.157:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are two kinds of illness.

an4.157:1.3.pli: Kāyiko ca rogo cetasiko ca rogo.

an4.157:1.4.pli: Dissanti, bhikkhave, sattā kāyikena rogena ekampi vassaṃ ārogyaṃ paṭijānamānā, dvepi vassāni ārogyaṃ paṭijānamānā, tīṇipi vassāni ārogyaṃ paṭijānamānā, cattāripi vassāni ārogyaṃ paṭijānamānā, pañcapi vassāni ārogyaṃ paṭijānamānā, dasapi vassāni ārogyaṃ paṭijānamānā, vīsatipi vassāni ārogyaṃ paṭijānamānā, tiṃsampi vassāni ārogyaṃ paṭijānamānā, cattārīsampi vassāni ārogyaṃ paṭijānamānā, paññāsampi vassāni ārogyaṃ paṭijānamānā, vassasatampi, bhiyyopi ārogyaṃ paṭijānamānā.
an4.157:1.4.eng: Some sentient beings are seen who can claim to be free of physical illness for a year, or two, or three years … even up to a hundred years or more.

an4.157:1.5.pli: Te, bhikkhave, sattā sudullabhā lokasmiṃ ye cetasikena rogena muhuttampi ārogyaṃ paṭijānanti, aññatra khīṇāsavehi.
an4.157:1.5.eng: But it’s very hard to find any sentient beings in the world who can claim to be free of mental illness even for an hour, apart from those who have ended the defilements.

an4.157:2.1.eng: There are four kinds of illness for those gone forth.

an4.157:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mahiccho hoti vighātavā asantuṭṭho itarītaracīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena.
an4.157:2.3.eng: To start with, a mendicant has many wishes, is frustrated, and is not content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an4.157:2.4.pli: So mahiccho samāno vighātavā asantuṭṭho itarītaracīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena pāpikaṃ icchaṃ paṇidahati anavaññappaṭilābhāya lābhasakkārasilokappaṭilābhāya.
an4.157:2.4.eng: Because of this, they focus their corrupt wishes on status, and on getting material things, honor, and popularity.

an4.157:2.5.pli: So uṭṭhahati ghaṭati vāyamati anavaññappaṭilābhāya lābhasakkārasilokappaṭilābhāya.
an4.157:2.5.eng: They try hard, strive, and make an effort to get these things.

an4.157:2.6.pli: So saṅkhāya kulāni upasaṅkamati, saṅkhāya nisīdati, saṅkhāya dhammaṃ bhāsati, saṅkhāya uccārapassāvaṃ sandhāreti.
an4.157:2.6.eng: They have an ulterior motive when they visit families. They have an ulterior motive when they sit down, when they speak on Dhamma, and even when they hold it in when they need to go to the toilet.

an4.157:2.7.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro pabbajitassa rogā.
an4.157:2.7.eng: These are the four kinds of illness for those gone forth.

an4.157:3.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an4.157:3.2.pli: ‘na mahicchā bhavissāma vighātavanto asantuṭṭhā itarītaracīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena, na pāpikaṃ icchaṃ paṇidahissāma anavaññappaṭilābhāya lābhasakkārasilokappaṭilābhāya, na uṭṭhahissāma na ghaṭessāma na vāyamissāma anavaññappaṭilābhāya lābhasakkārasilokappaṭilābhāya, khamā bhavissāma sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya pipāsāya ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṃ duruttānaṃ durāgatānaṃ vacanapathānaṃ, uppannānaṃ sārīrikānaṃ vedanānaṃ dukkhānaṃ tibbānaṃ kharānaṃ kaṭukānaṃ asātānaṃ amanāpānaṃ pāṇaharānaṃ adhivāsakajātikā bhavissāmā’ti.
an4.157:3.2.eng: ‘We will not have many wishes or be frustrated. We will be content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. We won’t focus our corrupt wishes on status, and on getting material things, honor, and popularity. We won’t try hard, strive, and make an effort to get these things. We will endure cold, heat, hunger, and thirst. We will endure the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles. We will endure rude and unwelcome criticism. We will put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.’
